block.p: Priceline.com, which earned its reputation with the name-your-own-price model for airline tickets, will soon try to interest you in bidding for a new commodity: cheap phone calls.

Priceline.com, which earned its reputation with the name-your-own-price model for airline tickets, will soon try to interest you in bidding for a new commodity: cheap phone calls.

The company began its Priceline Long Distance Service yesterday. Consumers can go to the company's Web site (www.priceline.com) to bid on blocks of long-distance time. Bids are accepted or rejected within 60 seconds.

After their bids are accepted, consumers use the Priceline credit as they would use any prepaid phone card. The customer first dials a toll-free number, then enters a password and begins using the time, which has already been charged to the customer's credit card. (Consumers don't have to change their primary long-distance carriers.) ''We wanted to boil down all the complicated long-distance pricing schemes to a simple equation: no hidden charges, no monthly fees, no minimum call times,'' said Daniel Schulman, Priceline's president and chief executive.

One way the company is trying to keep the service inexpensive is by routing calls over the networks of Internet telephony companies: Net2Phone, deltathree.com and zeroplus.com. Mr. Schulman said that during about a month of testing, the average block of time sought by each bid was four hours and that the average saving was about 40 percent off the best available long-distance packages.

James Vogtle, e-commerce research director at the Boston Consulting Group, said the Priceline service could mean savings for consumers, even beyond those offered by other carriers. ''The ong-distance market is a commodity market with lots of surplus capacity,'' Mr. Vogtle said. ''Consumers just might get better prices than they would be able to negotiate on their own.''
